title: 107_s610
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings. Congress finds that decommissioned firearms once used by law enforcement agencies have been involved in various crimes, including shootings at a Jewish community center and near a playground. Additionally, firearms stolen during shipment have been traced to crimes in Chicago. In the past 9 years, decommissioned firearms from law enforcement agencies have been linked to over 3,000 crimes, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. Additionally, State and local law enforcement departments often resell confiscated firearms, including assault weapons, that were involved in crimes. In the past 9 years, decommissioned firearms from law enforcement agencies have been linked to over 3,000 crimes, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. Some law enforcement departments resell confiscated firearms, including assault weapons, that were involved in crimes. Additionally, certain departments have adopted the practice of destroying decommissioned firearms. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 restricted assault weapons in circulation. Law enforcement departments in various states have started destroying decommissioned firearms to reduce the number of guns on the streets. The purpose of this Act is to prevent the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 restricted assault weapons in circulation, with law enforcement departments destroying decommissioned firearms to prevent their transfer to individuals. SEC. 3. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms, as long as they have a policy against transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State or local government must have a policy that prohibits transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals and requires their destruction, with an exception for transfer to law enforcement agencies. The Act prohibits transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals and requires their destruction, with an exception for transfer to law enforcement agencies. States or local governments receiving grants must use the funds to purchase new firearms. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS.

To request a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information.

SEC. 5. REGULATIONS. SEC. 5. REGULATIONS. The Attorney General must create regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment, outlining information and requirements for grant applications. SEC. 6. REPORTING. SEC. 6. REPORTING. A State or local government must report to the Attorney General within 2 years of receiving funds under this Act on its implementation. The report must include budget assurances for law enforcement agencies to purchase firearms without transferring decommissioned ones. SEC. 7. DEFINITION. SEC. 7. DEFINITION. The term "decommissioned firearm" refers to a firearm no longer in use by law enforcement or involved in a crime and no longer needed for evidence. "Firearm" and "person" have the same meanings as defined in specific sections of the United States Code. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005.
